summary: Free Upcoming 4 Pillars Events Offer Lifestyle Tips to Reverse Diabetes & Hypertension (Experts Offer Cooking, Exercise, Stress...
caption:
Free Upcoming 4 Pillars Events Offer Lifestyle Tips to Reverse Diabetes & Hypertension

(Experts Offer Cooking, Exercise, Stress Management & Socialization Techniques)

Riverside resident Delois Terry, a 75-year-old grandma, reversed her dangerously high diabetes numbers to below the diabetic range and her once sky-high blood pressure is consistently within the healthy spectrum.  She joins dozens of others who have enjoyed similar results.  What’s their secret?  You can find out at events sponsored by Lifestyle Medical Solutions and Brand New Day, a Medicare Advantage Health Plan with specialized programs to help members manage their diabetes, cardiovascular disease and/or chronic heart failure. “Control Your Diabetes & Hypertension Using the 4 Pillars” are free events open to the public.  Space is limited and reservations encouraged by calling 855-611-6401.

9/24/18 at 2 pm
Summerbell Room at The Mitten Building
345 N fifth St
Redlands, CA 92374

9/25/18 at 2 PM
The Eagle Glen Golf Club
1800 Eagle Glen Parkway
Corona, CA 92883

9/26/18 at 9am
Janet Goeske Senior Center
5257 Sierra St.
Riverside, CA 92504

Developed by Wayne Dysinger, MD, MPH to combat diabetes and hypertension, the 4 Pillars involve eating healthy, incorporating exercise into your life, managing stress and socializing.  The day’s event will include a cooking demonstration by nutritionist Laura Davis and each guest will receive a free copy of her pocket cookbook of easy-to-prepare meals designed to feed two.  Next, Dysinger will lead the group in some gentle exercises then offer tips to manage stress.  After a Q&A session, guests will be encouraged to mingle with fellow guests in a socialization exercise.  Immediately following, samples made from the healthy cookbook along with beverages will be served.
Dysinger has earned an international reputation as a leader in lifestyle medicine and is Chairman of the American Board of Lifestyle Medicine.  He also serves as medical director of the Lifestyle Medicine Institute and is a professor at Loma Linda University.
Brand New Day is the Medicare product name of Universal Care, Inc., a privately held California Knox-Keene Healthcare Service Plan licensed by the California Department of Managed Health Care and contracted with the Centers of Medicare and Medicaid Services as a Medicare Advantage contractor.
Established in 1983, Universal Care, Inc. is owned and operated by an experienced group of managed care executives and physicians.  For more information, visit BNDHMO.com or call (866) 255-4795.

title: Best Vegetarian Restaurants – Charlotte
body:
http://ifttt.com/images/no_image_card.pngCharlotte, North Carolina, has been in rapid development since the mid-00s. The restaurants and bars in this city reflect the changing needs of its residents. While this city’s cuisine traditionally focuses on seafood and barbecued pork, you can now find vegetarian restaurants that will provide you with an authentic North Carolina dining experience. Charlotteans have a fondness for comfort food and there is a growing appreciation in the city for East Asian dishes. 12 of the Best Vegetarian Restaurants in Charlotte, NC It can take a while to discover all the best vegetarian restaurants Charlotte has to offer. This list will help you find the best fit for your taste. 1. Fern Fern is an elegant all-vegetarian restaurant that promises “fresh flavors from the garden.” Their East Boulevard location has an old-fashioned, welcoming ambiance. In 2013, Fern was named one of Charlotte’s top 25 restaurants. Each dish at Fern is beautifully served. There are elaborate and refreshing salads, and you can order additions that include vegan cheeses, seared tempeh, and pumpernickel. Don’t miss out on the delicious toasts or the beet burger and make sure to try the apple cobblers or carrot cake for dessert. 2. Ma Ma Wok Although
[Read More …]

slug: memed完成7000多萬美元的新一輪融資
summary: MeMed完成7000多萬美元的新一輪融資
title: MeMed完成7000多萬美元的新一輪融資
body:
憑藉此輪融資，公司將加快開發開創性及時現場護理平臺，並推廣用於區分細菌性感染與病毒性感染的免疫試驗

以色列海法2018年9月20日電 /美通社/ –  

領先國際投資者參與新一輪融資，進一步鞏固了MeMed在宿主診斷領域的領導地位

MeMed 今天宣佈完成7000多萬美元的新一輪融資，參與此輪融資的新的和現有投資者包括平安全球領航基金(Ping An Global Voyager Fund)、富士康(Foxconn)、 Caesarea Medical Holdings、Clal Insurance、Phoenix Insurance、OurCrowd、Social Capital、WTI和維港投資(Horizons Ventures)，以及以早期投資能夠改變行業的公司而聞名的高淨值高層人員。

MeMed計劃將此次融資所得投資於以下三個領域：(i) 推廣用於區分細菌性與病毒性感染的突破性免疫系統試驗 MeMed BV ™，同時不斷生成能夠驗證試驗性能的大量臨床證據；(ii)完成開創性及時現場護理(POC)蛋白質測定平臺MeMed Key ™的開發、獲批和高端生產；(iii)拓展其創新試驗組合，透過整合機械學習和基於免疫的測定，應對重大臨床挑戰。

MeMed聯合創辦人兼行政總裁Eran Eden博士表示：「我們的技術既面臨嚴峻的臨床挑戰，也擁有巨大的市場機遇，投資者參與這輪融資的熱情就體現了這點。近十年來，透過與領先的學術和商業合作夥伴合作，我們已開發了MeMed BV ™，然後透過生成高質量的雙盲臨床證據，對其進行驗證。在MeMed Key ™和其他平臺上測定時，MeMed BV ()TM表現出了潛力，有望成為對抗耐藥菌的重要工具，耐藥菌是我們當代所面臨的最大醫療健康挑戰。除了這輪融資之外，我們還獲得了美國政府和歐盟的大力支持，鞏固了MeMed作為傳染性和炎症性疾病宿主診斷領域的全球領導者的地位。」

MeMed聯合創辦人兼技術總監Kfir Oved稱：「這些資源將加快開創性MeMed Key ™平臺的最終開發、獲批和生產進程。該平臺可在幾分鐘內運行MeMed BV ™試驗。重要的是，MeMed Key ™有可能讓及時現場護理的測定和診斷達到中心實驗室的精准水平。它將實現護理現場的多個其它常規和創新蛋白質和標誌物的測定，而這些蛋白質和標誌物目前只能在中心實驗室進行測定。這為診斷和管理各種其他疾病的患者創造了巨大的價值。」   

平安全球領航基金醫療總監、前賓州醫療中心(Penn State Medical Center)放射科創新和增值部門副教授兼主任Marco Huesch博士說：「這項振奮人心的創新將顯著增強那些需要區分細菌性感染和病毒性感染的醫生及患者的診斷和治療信心。除了讓患者顯著受益之外，該突破性技術還將應對更廣泛的人群所面臨的抗生素過度使用的問題，幫助緩解不斷加劇的抗生素耐藥性壓力。」

MeMed 簡介

MeMed 的使命是在合適的時間和地點，將人體免疫系統的複雜信號轉化為簡單的診斷觀點，改變我們治療傳染性和炎症性疾病的方式。近十年來，MeMed透過與全球範圍內的合作夥伴進行合作，開發和驗證了用於區分細菌性與病毒性感染的開創性免疫蛋白質標誌物MeMed BV™。它在對抗細菌的耐藥菌株方面不可或缺具，耐藥菌株是我們當代所面臨的最大醫療健康挑戰之一。作為酶聯免疫吸附測定(ELISA)形式的MeMed BV™，ImmunoXpert ™已在歐盟(CE-IVD)、瑞士和以色列獲批使用，目前已在這些國家和地區試銷。MeMed還正在開發MeMed Key™，該突破性平臺將在護理現場實現多個常規和創新蛋白質和標誌物的精准測定，其精准度有望達到中心實驗室水準。MeMed Key™能夠在幾分鐘內對MeMed BV™進行測定。如今，我們正在擴大我們與國際知名學術、商業和政府利益相關者之間的合作，以推進、驗證和促進我們平臺和試驗的全球可用性。詳情請瀏覽http://www.me-med.com/。

MeMed科學事務部副總裁Tanya Gottlieb
電郵：tanya.gottlieb@me-med.com

MeMed財務主管Kfir Emmer

電郵：kfir.emmer@me-med.com

電郵：kthomas@theruthgroup.com

blog.name: melodyshealthylife
blog.title: Melody's Healthy Life
blog.description:
Hi I'm Melody! I'm starting this blog to share my commitment to fitness and a healthy lifestyle. All of the pictures on my blog are ones that I have taken myself.
Canadian Born and Raised (:
Healthy Lifestyle Beginnings: June 3rd, 2016
Blog Creation: May 1st, 2017
Started Yoga: September 2016
Started Pilates: January 27, 2018

 



     visits as of October 17, 2017

summary: The biggest misconception of a healthy lifestyle is that the food choices have little stretching room. No Carbs, No Calories, No...
body:
Day 37

The biggest misconception of a healthy lifestyle is that the food choices have little stretching room. No Carbs, No Calories, No Sugar, No fun!

This is not at all the case. Unless we’re talking about PIZZA. Sometimes the only way to make this healthy is with cauliflower crust, ghee and veggie toppings.

Luckily, this is NOT that type of healthy pizza. This is for my “picky eater, pizza lovers”.

I’ve found a way to help that pizza craving. Its still processed but as little as possible and my kids love it. Seriously- I pack it for my 5 year olds lunch and he assembles it at school. Haven’t heard a complaint yet.

Ingredients

•Pita Bread 1 (60cal)

•Pizza Sauce 2 Tbsp (23cal)

•Pepperoni 3 slices (65cal)

•Shredded Mozzarella 3 Tbsp (40cal)

Cooking Time&Temp

•Broil on High for 5 minutes (or until cheese starts to brown)

188 cals per serving. Serving size 1 pizza

*Modify and Share*

*I use Del Grosso Old style Pizza Sauce because it has no unnecessary ingredients. Just tomatos and seasonings, plus I’ve tried my fair share and this one taste the best!

*I use Boar Head Slicing Pepperoni because besides the BHA and BHT preserves, its real pork and beef. You can use substitutions like veggies, turkey, etc.

*I use Joseph’s brand pita bread. Theres a never ending battle happening between the healthy and the healthier when it comes to carbs. I just try to make sure that whatever IT is, it says “Whole Wheat”. Whole wheat means the wheat was left as a whole, any other type of processing means they took out the wheat Bran and the wheat Germ. Those happen to be the nutrients in wheat. If I’m going to eat carbs, I might as well make sure its the least refined. It helps that this brand of pita adds in Oat Bran and Flax as well, making it a little bit more nutritious.

———————————————————

Don’t worry - my goal is to find the healthiest, unprocessed pizza that still taste like our favorite commercial pie! Till then, enjoy!

*I use Del Grosso Old style Pizza Sauce because it has no unnecessary ingredients. Just tomatos and seasonings, plus I’ve tried my fair share and this one taste the best!

*I use Boar Head Slicing Pepperoni because besides the BHA and BHT preserves, its real pork and beef. You can use substitutions like veggies, turkey, etc.

*I use Joseph’s brand pita bread. Theres a never ending battle happening between the healthy and the healthier when it comes to carbs. I just try to make sure that whatever IT is, it says “Whole Wheat”. Whole wheat means the wheat was left as a whole, any other type of processing means they took out the wheat Bran and the wheat Germ. Those happen to be the nutrients in wheat. If I’m going to eat carbs, I might as well make sure its the least refined. It helps that this brand of pita adds in Oat Bran and Flax as well, making it a little bit more nutritious.

———————————————————

Don’t worry - my goal is to find the healthiest, unprocessed pizza that still taste like our favorite commercial pie! Till then, enjoy!
trail.content:
Day 37

The biggest misconception of a healthy lifestyle is that the food choices have little stretching room. No Carbs, No Calories, No Sugar, No fun!

This is not at all the case. Unless we’re talking about PIZZA. Sometimes the only way to make this healthy is with cauliflower crust, ghee and veggie toppings.

Luckily, this is NOT that type of healthy pizza. This is for my “picky eater, pizza lovers”.

I’ve found a way to help that pizza craving. Its still processed but as little as possible and my kids love it. Seriously- I pack it for my 5 year olds lunch and he assembles it at school. Haven’t heard a complaint yet.

Ingredients

•Pita Bread 1 (60cal)

•Pizza Sauce 2 Tbsp (23cal)

•Pepperoni 3 slices (65cal)

•Shredded Mozzarella 3 Tbsp (40cal)

Cooking Time&Temp

•Broil on High for 5 minutes (or until cheese starts to brown)

188 cals per serving. Serving size 1 pizza

*Modify and Share*

*I use Del Grosso Old style Pizza Sauce because it has no unnecessary ingredients. Just tomatos and seasonings, plus I’ve tried my fair share and this one taste the best!

*I use Boar Head Slicing Pepperoni because besides the BHA and BHT preserves, its real pork and beef. You can use substitutions like veggies, turkey, etc.

*I use Joseph’s brand pita bread. Theres a never ending battle happening between the healthy and the healthier when it comes to carbs. I just try to make sure that whatever IT is, it says “Whole Wheat”. Whole wheat means the wheat was left as a whole, any other type of processing means they took out the wheat Bran and the wheat Germ. Those happen to be the nutrients in wheat. If I’m going to eat carbs, I might as well make sure its the least refined. It helps that this brand of pita adds in Oat Bran and Flax as well, making it a little bit more nutritious.

———————————————————

Don’t worry - my goal is to find the healthiest, unprocessed pizza that still taste like our favorite commercial pie! Till then, enjoy!

summary: 10 surprising facts on how the average person can really get in shape
title: 10 surprising facts on how the average person can really get in shape
body:
Gretchen Reynolds knows a thing or 2 concerning the frustrating globe of medical journals, wellness researches and study. As the author behind the preferred “Phys Ed” column on The New York Times ‘Well’ blog, Gretchen’s sifts via numerous short articles providing her guidance as well as solitarily changing the means millions of people work out. Her book, The First 20 Minutes, will assist also the most typical of viewers comprehend the science of physical fitness. The working mom and avid jogger, whose job has actually likewise appeared in O: The Oprah Magazine, goes directly to the specialists for responses that will maximize your goals. Read on for some shocking findings that will certainly permanently alter the means you exercise:

1. We were made to walk. A recent study, led by researchers at the University of Utah, dealt with zoologists to compare human locomotion to that of cheetahs and gazelles (animals who are organic runners). They equipped athletes of various ages with face masks and also asked them to run in three various styles determining their oxygen degrees for every. What they found was that running itself wasn’t effective in any way for people, walking was. “We consume more oxygen to run compared to the common mammal our size,” the scientists stated. So it seems if you’re looking to get someplace walking, rather than running, would be the very best alternative. If you have actually provided running a try as well as it’s except you, don’t really feel bad– walking is a terrific means to slim down and also stay in form while being the easiest on your body.

2. Justin Bieber can improve your workouts. “Our bodies are made to be relocated by music and also relocate to it,” claims Nina Kraus, Ph.D. as well as professor of neurobiology at Northwestern College. A current British study showed that males paying attention to high-tempo music while on a stationary bicycle sped up when their songs’s speed was raised. Whether it’s Bieber, Beyonce or Abba, tons your iPod with quickly, positive music that will certainly keep you keep you motivated.

3. Ditch the carbs. We’ve all listened to of carb-loading yet exactly what a lot of people do not know is that if you’re extremely working out for anything under a hr you don’t need additional carbs. Gretchen states, “If you’re not an affordable or significant professional athlete, you do not have to be interested in sports nutrition.” If you’re working out for greater than 2 hrs, she suggests eating a banana or Popsicle for energy– not an additional helping of pasta at dinner. Those of you chugging water while working out ought to quit that she alerts noting that over-hydration has claimed more lives during recent marathons compared to dehydration.

4. Chocolate milk is much better than Gatorade. While Gretchen dissuades you from altering way too much of your diet plan for daily exercise, what she does encourage is grabbing low-fat chocolate milk post-workout. Containing, “a practically excellent proportion of sugars as well as proteins,” delicious chocolate milk is perfect for power replenishment rather than costly healthy protein drinks and also powders. Canadian football celebrity Christine Sinclair vouches by this as well.

5. Weight train. Studies reveal that “any quantity of weightlifting boosted older people’s body composition”. Typically older people that added weights to their program included 1kilogram of muscular tissue to their bodies which is remarkable considering many people’s muscle mass actually decreases after age 50.

6. Your birthdays do not determine your age. In a McMaster study, mice were watched to see exactly how the effects of exercise affected the aging procedure. The results concluded that the mice that worked out frequently (in this instance 45 minutes of running on the wheel, three times per week) aged at slower rates than the mice that really did not do included workout. After five months, researchers discovered the running computer mice were much more vibrant, had a lot more hair as well as better equilibrium. They resembled, “little fury Betty Whites” they explained.

7. Sex can make you smarter. When male rats, in a Princeton College study, were provided “sexually responsive” ladies, the resulting activity created an, “boost in neurogenesis in their minds.” Essentially, sex developed brand-new cells in the human brain, an until just recently, scientists believed was impossible.

8. Your run time does count. Gretchen recommends running a mile as well as timing on your own if you’re aiming to get into the pastime. If you’re 40 and also can not run a 12-minute mile (or 1.6 kilometers) you are the least fit of the spectrum. Go for a nine-minute mile if you’re around 40, if you’re 30 or under goal for 7 mins. Simply 20 minutes suffices to make best use of health and wellness benefits. When it pertains to extending, do not bother with doing it ahead of time, Gretchen’s advice is to simply begin very easy by walking for a few minutes prior to starting your run.

9. Take your runs outside. Running inside on a treadmill deals with wind and modification in surface definition if you’re running inside you’re in fact utilizing 5 percent much less power than you would certainly be running outside. If you reside in Canada as well as running outdoors is only possible (emergency room … bearable) a few months of the year, the publication suggests setting your treadmill to a minimum of a degree one slope to much better simulate nature.

10. Move. Often. If you don’t exercise at all, guide encourages you to obtain available for also five minutes a day. The physical effects of activity begin to work almost right away. It’s never far too late to begin but simply make certain you’re regularly including size every couple of sessions. Your body and mind will certainly thanks– research studies reveal the longer you stick to a regular exercise routine, the higher decrease in your level of stress.

For more fascinating searchings for– like the number of raise you should have the ability to do and why you can stop doing crises– grab a duplicate of Gretchen Reynolds’s, The First 20 Minutes, $28. You could follow her on Twitter here.

Do you presently read Gretchen’s advice?

summary: Lifter in his 40s looking for conditioning that doesn't bore me to death via /r/Fitness
title: Lifter in his 40s looking for conditioning that doesn't bore me to death via /r/Fitness
body:
TLDR: a mid/advanced male lifter for general fitness in my mid 40s looking for conditioning advice which doesn’t break me or bore me to death.

​

I’m looking for recommendations to fit conditioning into my workout regime, something which improves my cardiovascular health and helps my strength training. As I’m in my 40s (I can’t say the m-word) my injury recovery isn’t that good anymore, so ability to do it safely for years on end is important.

I’ve lifted weights mostly in body-building or powerlifting style all my adult life, going to the gym religiously three times a week. Starting Strength, Lean Gains, body-part splits, upper-lower splits, push-pull splits, program hopping, pyramids, drop sets, supersets, you name it. Now I have a program I could stick to: I’ve done pretty much the same full-body workout for over three years, below for reference.

I’m a borderline gym rat but I’m no bodybuilder, and have never competed in anything. I’m fairly strong and in decent shape although my capacity for cardio isn’t that good. I’m healthy, eat a mostly paleo diet and do 16/8 intermittent fasting for years, and carry 15-20% bodyfat (measured with caliper) and roughly 25 BMI. I’m on the lean side of average build with decent muscle mass, but need to drop a few kilos to get back to where I like to be: average side of lean.

Full-body lifting program:

Tue:

  • Deadlifts (pyramid of mostly singles to build up to training 1RM)
  • Weighted chins
  • Incline dumbbell press
  • Strict OHP

Thu:

  • Front squats
  • Weighted pull-ups
  • Weighted dips
  • Push press

Sat:

  • Good mornings or straight-legged deads
  • Weighted chins
  • Weighted dips
  • Strict OHP

I’d increase the weights over a few months, and would reset down by about 20% maybe three times a year to start building up again. I’ve built most of my lifts up slowly but steadily. Deadlift and front squats haven’t grown as much as I’d like, and my shoulder isn’t in the greatest shape due to injury, but that’s another story.

Recently I’ve started getting a bit too many aches in my joints, and I’ve changed one day to do less weight and higher volume:

  • Bulgarian split squats per leg (bodyweight)
  • Push-ups (bodyweight)
  • Chin-ups or pull-ups or neutral grip pull-ups per cycle (bodyweight)
  • Band pull-aparts and other band work

Repeat the cycle three times. Dropping heavy lifting to only two days a week per body part got rid of the aches.

​

Now to the recommendation request. Should I add a conditioning day to my workout regime, or replace the above day with one? What kind of conditioning would fit my goals - general health fitness first, strength and mass second -, giving me something to work for years with low likelihood of hurting me, without boring me to death? So absolutely no LISS. Or crossfit.

Sled pushes and pulls or farmers walks or weighted lunges sound excellent, but they also may hurt my joints in the long term. Is HIIT the same? Perhaps high-volume accessory lifts done in a fast cycle? Going back to BJJ? Dancing, maybe?



Submitted September 20, 2018 at 05:47AM by Crawsh
via reddit https://ift.tt/2PPn7vG

Starting Strength, Lean Gains, body-part splits, upper-lower splits, push-pull splits, program hopping, pyramids, drop sets, supersets, you name it. Now I have a program I could stick to: I’ve done pretty much the same full-body workout for over three years, below for reference.

I’m a borderline gym rat but I’m no bodybuilder, and have never competed in anything. I’m fairly strong and in decent shape although my capacity for cardio isn’t that good. I’m healthy, eat a mostly paleo diet and do 16/8 intermittent fasting for years, and carry 15-20% bodyfat (measured with caliper) and roughly 25 BMI. I’m on the lean side of average build with decent muscle mass, but need to drop a few kilos to get back to where I like to be: average side of lean.

Full-body lifting program:

Tue:

  • Deadlifts (pyramid of mostly singles to build up to training 1RM)
  • Weighted chins
  • Incline dumbbell press
  • Strict OHP

Thu:

  • Front squats
  • Weighted pull-ups
  • Weighted dips
  • Push press

Sat:

  • Good mornings or straight-legged deads
  • Weighted chins
  • Weighted dips
  • Strict OHP

I’d increase the weights over a few months, and would reset down by about 20% maybe three times a year to start building up again. I’ve built most of my lifts up slowly but steadily. Deadlift and front squats haven’t grown as much as I’d like, and my shoulder isn’t in the greatest shape due to injury, but that’s another story.

Recently I’ve started getting a bit too many aches in my joints, and I’ve changed one day to do less weight and higher volume:

  • Bulgarian split squats per leg (bodyweight)
  • Push-ups (bodyweight)
  • Chin-ups or pull-ups or neutral grip pull-ups per cycle (bodyweight)
  • Band pull-aparts and other band work

Repeat the cycle three times. Dropping heavy lifting to only two days a week per body part got rid of the aches.

​

Now to the recommendation request. Should I add a conditioning day to my workout regime, or replace the above day with one? What kind of conditioning would fit my goals - general health fitness first, strength and mass second -, giving me something to work for years with low likelihood of hurting me, without boring me to death? So absolutely no LISS. Or crossfit.

Sled pushes and pulls or farmers walks or weighted lunges sound excellent, but they also may hurt my joints in the long term. Is HIIT the same? Perhaps high-volume accessory lifts done in a fast cycle? Going back to BJJ? Dancing, maybe?

blog.description: Promoting Health & Wellness through Chakras & Natural Stones.

title: Wellness without deprivation...
body:
Along with opening and aligning your Chakras, we all must have over all health and wellness, which means how we think and what we consume.

We now have the pleasure of working with an extraordinary company, Heartfelt Health Coaching in connecting the dots on healthy clean eating and overall wellness. They not only provide guided programs to keep you on track, they also provide coaching to ensure this is a long lasting life-altering experience.

Holistic Health Coach Jessica Rinzuello has created a unique opportunity for new followers. On her website www.heartfelthealthcoaching.com you can now receive a FREE digital copy of her new ebook The Ultimate Guide to Shopping for Clean Food. You will also have an opportunity to download Fall Superfoods Guide. This guide is packed with information including the top 13 SUPERFOODS for Fall and why it’s important to “eat with the seasons”. These are both limited time offers to new followers that sign up for the sites newsletter.

Check it out and please let us know what you think! Sign up for the newsletter, get the books and join us on this amazing path to sustainable health and total wellness… Namaste
